title: Ops Resilience: Restoration Race
description: Grid secured. Now comes the hard part: restoring power to 200,000 homes and businesses without triggering another cascade failure. Every decision affects real people.

software-engineer.title: Run the Power Restoration Sequence
software-engineer.instruction: Automated scripts will bring each station back online safely — but they must run in the right sequence or you risk overloading the healthy parts of the grid. Put the restoration steps in order.
software-engineer.hint: The whole grid depends on the main transmission lines. Hospitals and emergency services come before residential areas. Test before you go full-scale.

items.label: Confirm every compromised station has been wiped and is definitely clean
Bring back the main transmission stations that supply power to multiple zones
Run a test load to verify the backbone can handle the demand before connecting more
Restore district stations in priority order — hospitals and critical services first
Restore residential areas last, zone by zone based on grid capacity

data-scientist.title: Find the Safe Restoration Speed
data-scientist.instruction: Restoring power too fast can overload the lines and cause another blackout. Based on safety tests over the last 4 hours (percentage of normal load the grid safely handled), predict the maximum safe percentage of power you can restore per hour without risking a cascade failure.
data-scientist.hint: The grid can safely handle more power each hour. How much did the capacity grow between hours 1 and 2? Between 2 and 3? 3 and 4?

cloud-engineer.title: Secure the Stations Before Restoring Power
cloud-engineer.instruction: The compromised control systems need to be fully secured before going back online. People are still without power, so time matters. What do you do?
cloud-engineer.hint: Remember that 200,000 people are without power — but restoring a system that still has the attacker inside just hands them back control.

options.label: Complete rebuild from scratch — every compromised device gets a fresh install of everything. Takes 6 hours but you're 100% certain the attacker left no traces.
Surgically remove only the identified malicious code and close the specific holes used in the attack. Done in 2 hours but there's a 15% chance of missing something hidden.

Bring systems back online under intense observation. If the attacker is still hiding, they'll reveal themselves when they try to move again. Risky but gives the best intelligence on what they left behind.
Replace the physical hardware entirely. The most expensive option and takes 12 hours, but eliminates any possibility of hidden software surviving at a deep level.
